body.name: Yummy: A History of Desserts (A Graphic Novel)
editorialReviews: Editorial Reviews About the Author Victoria Grace Elliott is the creator of the webcomic Balderdash! or, a tale of two witches. Yummy: A History of Desserts is her graphic novel debut. She's a queer Southern illustrator and comic artist living in Austin, Texas.

body.description: Cake is delicious, and comics are awesome: this exciting nonfiction graphic novel for kids combines both! Explore the history of desserts through a fun adventure with facts, legends, and recipes for readers to try at home.Have you ever wondered who first thought to freeze cream? Or when people began making sweet pastry shells to encase fruity fillings? Peri is excited to show you the delicious history of sweets while taking you around the world and back! The team-up that made ice cream cones! The mistake that made brownies! Learn about and taste the true stories behind everyone’s favorite treats, paired with fun and easy recipes to try at home. After all, sweets—and their stories—are always better when they’re shared!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Awesome read! Such a cute book. :) Neat history and beautifully illustrated!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Cute History of Desserts with Food Sprites
reviews.reviewText: “Yummy: A History of Desserts” is a baking history comic (written, illustrated, colored, & lettered) by Victoria Grace Elliott. Three food sprites (Peri, Fee, & Fada) take you through the history of various desserts, baked treats, & confections from their ancient origins & up til present. This is a very cute comic about baking. The sprites are adorable & each one has an individual personality / role (Peri is the main researcher & spokesperson / leader(?) / storyteller, Fee dresses up / cosplays historical figures for interview segments, & Fada heads the Science Lad). Some chapters are longer due to focusing on larger baking categories (cake, cookies) & others are more brief / spotlight chapters focused on more specific desserts (macarons). While not super in depth (it is aimed for children / all ages), I did learn a lot. There’s a lot of focus on how global dessert history is & how cultures have interacted & modified various sweet foodstuffs. & of course, there are some recipes, which the sprites actually make in the panels.The art is very very cute. Kawaii even. This is definitely a lighter, nicer read, but it doesn’t lack for content. I hope the author writes another, as it is left open given how many more desserts could be covered.Good for anyone who likes baking, cute art, or a calming / fun / chill read. 💜But where to shelve it? With my other cookbooks? Or comics? 😅😹💜

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Absolutely delightful and charming exploration into the history, science, and culture of sweets!
reviews.reviewText: I'm completely blown away by this book.The illustrations are enchanting and beautiful, the characters are goofy and fun, and the dives into the backgrounds of our favorite treats taught me so much about foods we just sort of take for granted.From cakes and cookies, to ice cream and gummies, this book explores the rich and tasty history of the origins, names, and evolutions of desserts, answering questions like:"Are apple pies as American as... uh.. apple pie?""What exactly does each ingredient in a chocolate chip cookie do?""Why are red velvet cakes red, anyway?"And of course, scattered throughout like sprinkles on an ice cream sundae, are some of the most fun and illustrative recipes to try out for yourself and experience the magical delicious world we live in.Kudos to author and illustrator Victoria Grace Elliot for one of the most wonderful and unique books I've ever put my hands on.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars My 11 year old absolutely loved this book for his summer reading assignment
reviews.reviewText: My son said he loved every second of this book. He normally doesn't like non-fiction books but this book took non-fiction to a whole other level! Definitely Recommend !

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Love it! So cute!
reviews.reviewText: Gonna buy 2 more when I can cuz it was so cute I gifted one to a little cousin, but I have a niece I want to gift one to and I want to keep one for myself like I had originally intended lol

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Packed with information and adorable illustrations!
reviews.reviewText: This graphic comic style book is amazing! The illustrations are colorful, fresh, unique and fun! The facts and information are interesting and worldly. It definitely exceeded my expectations. I hope this author continues to publish books, my children both adore her first published work!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Educational and adorable
reviews.reviewText: This book was not only visually pleasing, but educational and funny as well! I love the awareness of cultural influences mentioned throughout as well. Would love to see more some day!
